BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from northwesterly directions, visible wind slabs will form especially above approximately 2300 m. They are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released even by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Caution is to be exercised in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.

In particular in steep rocky terrain dry loose snow avalanches are possible above approximately 2300 m, in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2300 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers as the day progresses in particular on very steep sunny slopes, in particular below approximately 2300 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is not distinctly layered. The new snow of last week has bonded well with the old snowpack in all aspects.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger will persist. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 5 cm of snow has fallen. The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of warming during the day mostly small avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2400 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2500 m, especially at their margins. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. As a consequence of warming during the day medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 5 cm of snow has fallen. The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are mostly small but in some cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: More recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above approximately 2400 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. Mostly avalanches are only small. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of mild temperatures the snow drift accumulations stabilised on Monday. As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind from variable directions, mostly small wind slabs will form on Tuesday. They will be deposited on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. As a consequence of wind from variable directions, further wind slabs will form above approximately 1700 m. The wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northwesterly directions, wind slabs will form in the course of the day especially above approximately 2200 m.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers as the day progresses in particular on very steep sunny slopes, in particular below approximately 2300 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is not distinctly layered. The new snow of last week has bonded well with the old snowpack in all aspects.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger will persist. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some regions 5 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1400 m. The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Adjacent to ridgelines the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable.
The wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. Wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by small loads. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The sometimes large wind slabs represent the main danger. They will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some snow fell on Monday in some localities. More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and the strong to storm force northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Wednesday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form in particular along the border with France. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2500 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes above approximately 2500 m, especially at their margins. As a consequence of warming during the day individual small and medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported some snow. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: At high altitude and in gullies and bowls individual small avalanches are possible. These can be released by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At intermediate and high altitudes a little snow is lying. The sometimes strong wind has transported some snow. The wind slabs are shallow. These are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and generally at high altitudes. Little snow will fall during the night. This snow is bonding quite well with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of warming during the day mostly small avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and the strong to storm force northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Wednesday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The wind slabs represent the main danger.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. In particular in the south and at the base of rock walls mostly small moist loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Above approximately 1400 m only a little snow is lying.
